Abyssinian: Warm, ruddy coat (often golden, red, or fawn)
Sleek, short coat with a ticked pattern
Bengal: Pronounced M shape on the forehead
Distinctive coat pattern with spots or rosettes
Leopard-like spots or rosettes on the fur
Short, sleek coat with a distinctive spotted or marbled pattern
Birman: Color-point pattern (darker fur on ears, face, paws, and tail)
Distinctive "gloves" of white fur on the paws
British Shorthair: Broad, round head with a short nose
Typically solid coat colors or a classic tabby pattern
Short, dense coat with a plush feel
Large, round eyes, often copper or gold in color
Ears are broad at the base and slightly rounded at the tips
Egyptian Mau: Loose skin flap extending from the flank to the hind leg
Silvery, bronze, or smoke coat colors
Maine Coon: High cheekbones and a square muzzle
Whiskers (Maine Coons have long, prominent whiskers)
Long, flowing fur with a mane-like ruff around the neck
Pointed ears with tufts of fur at the tips
Ragdoll: colorpoint coat pattern (darker face, ears, paws, and tail)
Russian Blue: Upright, large ears with a slightly rounded tip
Siamese: Light-colored body with darker points (ears, face, paws, and tail)
Sleek, slender body with long legs
Sphynx: Hairlessness or very fine, short coat
american bulldog: White coat often with patches of other colors
Short, smooth coat with a variety of color patterns
american pit bull terrier: Broad, wide head with pronounced cheek muscles
Tail that is thick at the base and tapers to a point
Solid color or brindle coat pattern
basset hound: Distinct, heavy bones and large paws
Tri-color coat patterns often with large patches of white, black, and brown
beagle: Tricolor coat (typically black, tan, and white)
boxer: short coat, typically fawn or brindle with white markings
distinctive black mask around the face
chihuahua: Short, smooth coat (or longer but typically finer)
Tail that curls over the back
english cocker spaniel: Feathered fur on legs and belly
english setter: elongated face with a pronounced muzzle
german shorthaired: Broad, expressive face with longer snout
Solid liver color on the head
Longer legs and a more athletic build
Short, dense fur with a distinctive liver (brown) and white coat pattern
Presence of a dog in the photo
High-set, floppy ears that lie close to the head
Short, sleek coat with a mix of liver (brown) and white or roan spots
Distinctive ticking or speckled pattern on the coat
great pyrenees: Double dew claws on hind legs
havanese: Tightly curled tail that often arches over the back
Distinctive tail curled over the back
Longer ears that hang down, covered in long fur
japanese chin: Flatter face with a short snout and broad forehead
Long, silky coat often black and white or red and white
V-shaped feathered ears set high on the head
Feathered tail that curls over the back
Long, flowing fur particularly around the body, chest, and tail
keeshond: Dense, double coat with a plush, mane-like ruff
Fluffy tail curled over the back
leonberger: lion-like mane around the neck and chest area
Thick, double coat with a mane-like ruff around the neck
miniature pinscher: Black and tan or chocolate and tan coloring
newfoundland: Generally darker coat colors (black, brown, or Landseer - black and white)
pomeranian: Bushy tail curled over the back
Dense double coat with a fluffy appearance
Plumed tail that curls over the back
Typically lighter colors (such as orange, cream, or white)
Prominent mane around neck and chest
saint bernard: Distinctive tri-color coat (white with brown and black markings)
Ears that are set high and hang close to the head
Mask: Saint Bernards usually have a black "mask" around their eyes
Distinctive facial structure: Saint Bernards have a more pronounced brow ridge and a broader snout
samoyed: smiling facial expression (often referred to as the "Sammy smile")
bushy tail that curls over the back
scottish terrier: Black, wheaten, or brindle coat color
shiba inu: Reddish, sesame, or cream fur colors
Distinctive markings on face, chest, and legs
staffordshire bull terrier: Deep chest with a distinct tuck-up in the abdomen
Ears that are sometimes cropped or naturally semi-erect
Tail is relatively thick and tapers to a point, carried low but not docked
wheaten terrier: Distinctive facial hair, including beard and mustache
Tail held up and usually docked
yorkshire terrier: Long, flowing hair on both the body and the face
Distinct topknot often tied with a bow
